that heterosexual men in committed
relationships become uncomfortable
around women that they find attractive
after they've been given a dose of the
hormone oxytocin oxytocin is a hormone
that in women stimulates contractions
during childbirth and triggers the
production of breast milk it's sometimes
known as the nurturing hormone for this
reason but its effect on men is less
clear in the new study done at the
University of Bonn researchers gave
either oxytocin or a placebo to two
groups of committed straight men 45
minutes later the men were introduced to
a female experimenter that these
subjects described as hot hot hot the

as well as single men tested in a

that helps keep family bonds strong so

yawning is probably the most famous form
of contagious behavior when you see
someone yawn you usually do it too it's
such a widespread reflex that the
inability to yawn when someone else does
has been used as an indicator for neural
disorders like autism why we do this
isn't really clear though there are lots
of theories that sometimes are taught as
fact for this week we learned that the
reflex goes back very far in our
evolutionary history and the journal
PLoS ONE a pair of Italian biologists
say that they documented contagious
yawning among bonobos the great apes
that are closely related to chimps and
to us while studying bonobos in
captivity the scientists found that Apes
regularly yawn within a minute of seeing
another ape do the same what's more they
found that the reflex was much more
contagious among individuals that share
close personal bonds especially family
members then among Apes from different
groups this mirrors the responses seen
in humans who are more apt to yawn when
they see a friend or family member do it
than when they see a stranger do it
though this sheds a lot of light on what
if any evolutionary purpose contagious
yawning might have but the researchers

someone else's physical behavior is a

pitching believe it or not a team of
British scientists has put a lot of time
and thought into studying why people
suddenly feel itchy when they see
someone else scratching themselves and
the journal PNAS psychologists say that
they showed videos to 51 volunteers of
people either scratching themselves or
just tapping their arms and legs about
65% of the subjects who saw the
scratching videos started scratching
themselves which the scientists say
makes itching the most contagious
behavior ever measured more than yawning
which averages 50% in people or laughter
at 47% but they also use questionnaires
and other tools to conduct personality

ones that reacted most strongly to the

so the psychologists say itching may be

weirdest disorder you'll hear about this
week I hope some of you have been asking
to learn more about a strange new
disease that's gotten some attention
lately a vector-borne disease that
causes a sudden and severe allergy to
meet the media ever so good at headline
writing or describe it as a kind of
reverse zombie plague that turns people
into vegetarians well I've looked into
it and brace yourself it's kind of true
the condition was first reported last
year but it wasn't until July that the
mystery behind it finally seemed to be
solved by one dr. Susan Wolverine her
colleagues at Virginia Commonwealth
University after investigating several
strange cases of people in the
southeastern United States going into
unexplained allergic shock they
determined that all of the patients had
two things in common they had all eaten
red meat and had all been bitten by or
lived in the range of a kind of arachnid
found in the South called the Lone Star
tick it turns out that the saliva of
this tick contains a sugar that's also
found in certain kinds of meat the sugar
known as alpha-gal is produced by most
mammals like cows and pigs and deer but
not by primates we humans cannot make it
on our own the tick bite caused the
patient's immune systems to form
antibodies to this new sugar and as a
result whenever people ate meat their
natural defenses started to attack the
alpha-gal that they had ingested from
the meat and the unholy terror that
their immune systems unleashed caused
some pretty severe symptoms like hives
difficulty breathing swollen tongue and
like I mentioned shock unlike other
tick-borne diseases like Lyme disease
this condition appears to be permanent
and untreatable but patients can still
eat the meat of non mammals like chicken
turkey and fish so they're not doomed to
a life of vegetarianism if you were
worried about that still the disease is
one for the record books it's the first
known allergy to be transmitted by an
animal bite it's also the only food
allergy that's triggered by a sugar
instead of a protein the interesting
thing here is that if the world suddenly
you know came down with this disease on
a planet-wide scale that might not be a
good thing for like dairy farmers and
people who really
like red meat but it would be a good
thing for the earth as a whole if you
want to learn more about the tremendous
impact that eating red meat has on the
world you can check out our
overpopulation video a fascinating
conundrum I know that here in Montana it
would kind of destroy the economy so I'm
not really sure where I come down on
this if you could in effect the entire
world with this disease wouldn't you do
it
